results.headline: Going It Alone on the Road to Motherhood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Comes Love

results.summary_short: “First Comes Love” chronicles a Brooklyn filmmaker’s journey to motherhood through a sperm donor.

results.headline: On a Sicilian Island, Boat People Who Can’t Be Ignored

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terraferma

results.summary_short: In the Italian film “Terraferma,” a flood of African refugees complicate the lives of a struggling fisherman and his family.

results.headline: Hate at First Sight, With Love and Its Hurdles to Follow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ramaiya Vastavaiya

results.summary_short: In the Bollywood film “Ramaiya Vastavaiya,” at a wedding celebration, the bride’s playful cousin falls in love with a poor village girl.

results.headline: The Ninth Circle of Law Enforcement

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of R.I.P.D.

results.summary_short: In “R.I.P.D.,” Jeff Bridges and Ryan Reynolds are members of a heavenly police force that hunts dead villains and sends them to hell.

results.headline: Homeownership Has Its Perils

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Conjuring

results.summary_short: In James Wan’s horror tale “The Conjuring,” Lili Taylor and Ron Livingston are terrorized by the bumps and creaks around them.

results.headline: Old Friends Confront Dreams Deferred

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Words

results.summary_short: “Big Words” is a wistful tapestry of male disaffection that explores weighty themes like race, class, sexual orientation, politics and the evolution of rap music.

results.headline: The Rules, Not the Labor, May Kill Their Plans

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still Mine

results.summary_short: “Still Mine” is a love story about a couple in their late 80s who are keenly aware that after spending 61 years together and raising seven children, their time is running out.

results.headline: The Making of a (Fake) Rock Band

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Colossus

results.summary_short: In “Colossus,” the director, Mark Hendrickson, creates a vérité documentary about an “artificial band” that is all about manipulation.

results.headline: Do Six-Ton Captives Dream of Freedom?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blackfish

results.summary_short: The documentary “Blackfish” considers the story of Tilikum, a bull orca, in a scathing look at SeaWorld.

results.headline: Mass Murder? Gee, That Was Fun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Act of Killing

results.summary_short: “The Act of Killing” takes viewers inside the minds and motives of the guilty — in this case, those who massacred as many as 2.5 million Indonesians in the 1960s.

results.headline: Feeding on Memories
results.display_title: The ROMEOWS (Retired Older Men Eating Out Wednesdays)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The ROMEOWS (Retired Older Men Eating Out Wednesdays)

results.summary_short: There’s nothing flashy about the subjects of “The Romeows” — Retired Older Men Eating Out Wednesdays — but what they’ve created matters.

results.headline: Frolicking in a Musical Metropolis Playground

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rooftop

results.summary_short: Romance, rivalry and urban fantasy unfold in “The Rooftop,” a musical action film that pays homage to everyone from Busby Berkeley to to the Coen brothers.

results.headline: They Lost Even Before Getting to Las Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evidence

results.summary_short: Detectives charged with identifying the killer responsible for a clutch of bodies found in a derelict gas station in the Nevada desert seek clues on damaged video.

results.headline: He Didn’t Save the World, Just 669 Children

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nicky's Family

results.summary_short: “Nicky’s Family” documents how Nicholas Winton, now 104, gave up a 1938 skiing holiday to answer a friend’s request for help in Prague and didn’t stop helping until the war’s beginning stopped him.

results.headline: In ‘RED 2,’ Retired Special Ops Agents Can’t Relax

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red 2

results.summary_short: In the action-comedy “RED 2,” retired agents and mercenaries aren’t content to kick back; they load their guns to save the world from nuclear disaster.

results.headline: Mom Is a Drug Lord, and Gore Is a Narcotic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Only God Forgives

results.summary_short: “Only God Forgives,” a blood-drenched action movie, includes one character who plays God and sings karaoke.

results.headline: New Jersey Is Just So Embarrassing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girl Most Likely

results.summary_short: “Girl Most Likely,” directed by Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini, sends Kristen Wiig on a downward spiral that leaves her living with her gaudily accented mom.

results.headline: When the Fight Came Home

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Copperhead

results.summary_short: Billy Campbell plays a New York farmer who was no fan of slavery but against the Civil War, leading an antislavery firebrand to turn the town against him.

results.headline: The Lessons of a Pimp
results.display_title: Iceberg Slim: Portrait of a Pimp

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iceberg Slim: Portrait of a Pimp

results.summary_short: Ice-T has produced “Iceberg Slim: Portrait of a Pimp,” a documentary told through talking-head admirers, including Chris Rock and Snoop Dogg.

results.headline: Scissors, Shaver and Salvation for a Young Barber

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Playa

results.summary_short: The job of custom barber is a Colombian teenager’s ticket to a world beyond his poor family and rough past in “La Playa D.C.”
